translated: Points of Controversy
The Great Fifty
The thirteenth section
Face-to-face
“Does one who is face-to-face abandon fetters?”
“Yes.”

original: Ratto rāgaṁ jahati, duṭṭho dosaṁ jahati, mūḷho mohaṁ jahati, kiliṭṭho kilese jahatīti?
analyzed: rattaḥ rāgam jahati duṭṭhaḥ dosam jahati mūḷhaḥ moham jahati kiliṭṭhaḥ kilese jahati iti
translated: “Is one who is passionate able to abandon passion? Is one who is hateful able to abandon hate? Is one who is deluded able to abandon delusion? Is one who is soiled able to abandon defilements?”
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the four noble truths?” …

original: rāgena rāgaṁ jahati, dosena dosaṁ jahati, mohena mohaṁ jahati, kilesehi kilese jahatīti?
analyzed: rāgena rāgam jahati dosena dosam jahati mohena moham jahati kilesehi kilese jahati iti
translated: “Is one who is passionate able to abandon passion through passion? Is one who is hateful able to abandon hate through hate? Is one who is deluded able to abandon delusion through delusion? Is one who is soiled able to abandon defilements through defilements?”
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the four noble truths?” …

analyzed: rāgaḥ citta sampayuttaḥ maggo citta sampayutto ti
translated: “Is passion associated with the mind? Is the path associated with the mind?”
“Yes.”
“Is there a meeting together and association of two kinds of contact and of two kinds of consciousness?
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the four noble truths?” …
“Is passion unwholesome? Is the path wholesome?”
“Yes.”

original: Kusalākusalā sāvajjānavajjā hīnapaṇītā kaṇhasukkasappaṭibhāgā dhammā sammukhībhāvaṁ āgacchantīti?
analyzed: kusala akusalā sāvajja anavajjāḥ hīna paṇītā kaṇha sukka sappaṭibhāgāḥ dhammā sammukhībhāvam āgacchanti iti
translated: “Do wholesome and unwholesome, blameworthy and blameless, inferior and superior, dark and bright states with their opposites come into presence?”

analyzed: na ha ivam vattabbe pe  kusala akusalā pe
translated: “He is not to be spoken of as …🔽“He is not to be spoken of as wholesome or unwholesome …
“Do wholesome and unwholesome, blameworthy and blameless, inferior and superior, dark and bright states with their opposites come into presence?”
“Yes.”
“Has it not been said by the Blessed One:

analyzed: cattāri imāni bhikkhave su vidūra vidūrāni
translated: “Monks, there are these four things that are very far away.
What four?
The sky and the earth,🔽This is the first thing that is very far away. …

original: idaṁ paṭhamaṁ suvidūravidūraṁ …pe… tasmā sataṁ dhammo asabbhi ārakā”ti.
analyzed: idam paṭhamam su vidūra vidūram tasmai satam dhammaḥ
translated: The Dhamma of the good is far from the bad.”
Is there such a discourse?
You’ve misquoted the Buddha.
You shouldn’t say that.
“The wholesome and the unwholesome …
come into the vicinity?”
Does one who has come into the vicinity abandon the fetters?
You’ve misquoted the Buddha.
Hasn’t the Buddha said that:
‘When his mind is thus concentrated, purified, bright, unblemished, rid of defilement, flexible, malleable, steady, and attained to imperturbability,

analyzed: āsavānam khaya ñāṇāya cittam abhininnāmeti iti
translated: he directs it to knowledge of the destruction of the pollutants.’
Is there such a discourse?
You’ve misquoted the Buddha.
You shouldn’t say that.
“One who has come into the vicinity abandons the fetters.”

analyzed: na vattabba  sammukhībhūtaḥ sayojanam jahati iti
translated: You shouldn’t say that.
“One who has come into the vicinity abandons the fetters.”🔽You’ve misquoted the Buddha.
Hasn’t the Buddha said that:

original: “tassa evaṁ jānato evaṁ passato kāmāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati …pe…
analyzed: tassa evam jānataḥ evam passataḥ kāma āsavā api cittam vimuccati pe
translated: ‘When he knows and sees in this way, his mind is freed from the pollutant of sensuality, from the pollutant of (craving for) continued existence, and from the pollutant of ignorance.

analyzed: avijjā āsavā api cittam vimuccati iti 🔽atthā iva suttanto ti
translated: His mind is freed and he knows that it is freed.🔽He understands that greed is abandoned in him,
“The past.”

analyzed: tena hi sammukhībhūtaḥ sayojanam jahati iti
translated: “Well then, does one abandon the fetters when they are present?”
The Discussion of the Present is finished.
